Award.AwardTitle: Nahuatl Language Documentation Project: Sierra Norte de Puebla [ISO 639 azz]

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Documenting a language occurs at many levels, and the most detailed is often the most useful. Specialized knowledge about the plants and animals in the ecosystem the language has evolved in is a particularly useful segment of the language both for native speakers and for science at large. In partnership with an indigenous cooperative, a filmmaking collective, academic scholars, and computational linguists, Dr. Jonathan D. Amith will lead a three-year Nahuatl language documentation effort in the Sierra Norte de Puebla. One goal is to develop an extensive set of materials: a detailed dictionary; a basic descriptive grammar; and a 75-hour corpus of time-coded transcriptions of digital audio and video covering endangered genres of discourse and vanishing cultural knowledge, including ethnobiology, dance, stories, personal testimonials, and village histories. A professional film-making collective will produce three or four 27-minute educational documentaries. A second goal is to develop a set of software tools for processing and presentation of the materials. Some of the tools will be language specific; a morphological parser to analyze Nahuatl words, separating the affixes from the stem and thus facilitating dictionary lookup as well as permanent archiving of parsed and glossed time-coded transcriptions. Most of the tools, however, will have general applications in documentary endeavors and will be made freely available. One, WebScriber, converts a time-coded transcription into a Web page with line-by-line playback. Another, Prompter/Segmenter, prompts speakers from a list of lexical items and then segments the resulting sound file in such a way as to facilitate linking to an online dictionary. Finally, Cobbler is a utilities program for data management of files written in Shoebox, the most commonly-used program for field linguists.

Results of this project will greatly expand our knowledge of the descendant languages of the Aztec empire, with a special emphasis on the ecosystem. To date the Nahuatl project has collected 1,151 botanical specimens (all professionally mounted), about 300 entomological specimens, 19 fish, 24 arachnids, and 22 reptiles, and some 50 objects of material culture (nets, baskets, arrows, rope, etc.). Most are linked to relevant recorded and transcribed texts, such as the folklore associated with different types of grasshoppers, or how to make and use arrows. With the internet interface that allows the exploration of digitized versions of all of these items, both indigenous researchers and those from outside have an unusually large collection of materials to draw from.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nahuatl (the language of the Aztecs) is best considered a group of closely related, often significantly distinct, languages. The "Nahuatl Language Documentation Project (NLDP): Sierra Norte de Puebla" is Amith's second major documentation project on a Nahuatl language, the first having targeted the Nahuatl language spoken in central state of Guerrero. Each has produced a large corpus of time-coded transcriptions of digital recordings, a partial grammar in draft form, and an extensive dictionary, material that creates a substantial base for comparative study. The Sierra Norte de Puebla project, based in the village of San Miguel Tzinacapan (municipality of Cuetzalan del Progreso), has itself yielded 955 separate recordings, all transcribed in time-coded format (linking the transcription to a segment of the recording), totaling 186 hours; fifteen chapters of a proposed 51-chapter grammar; and a dictionary of 8140 entries presented in a manuscript of 3,779 pages. All materials have been deposited and are freely available (open access) at the Archive of Indigenous Languages of Latin America, University of Texas. In building a documentary corpus Amith has focused particularly on the nomenclature, classification, and use of plants (577 recordings) and animals (103 recordings). He has collected and deposited in herbaria and museums over 1000 specimens, identified by expert taxonomists, as a physical back-up to his linguistic data. This strategy combines documentation of an endangered language with documentation of endangered cultural knowledge. Moreover, this thematic focus has created the foundation for comparative work in the domain of Indigenous natural history across Nahuatl and other Mesoamerican languages, such as Yoloxóchitl (Pacific Coast of Guerrero) Mixtec and several Totonac languages across the Sierra Norte and Nororiental of Puebla, languages with which Amith is also working.

From a linguistic perspective, the Nahuat (there is no /tl/ phoneme in this language) spoken in the municipality of Cuetzalan is interesting for several reasons. First, it shows the impact of Totonac both in its grammar (such as the placement of the words for 'only', 'already' and 'still' after verbs, nouns, and quantifiers) and lexicon (with multiple lexical borrowings and calques from Totonac, almost all in the semantic domain of plants and animals). Second, many speakers in the municipality, probably influenced by the purist language ideology of an Indigenous radio station and an Indigenous-run cooperative, demonstrate a tendency to "translate" Spanish grammatical structures and word meanings into Nahuat. That is, they either use Nahuat words in non-Nahuat (Spanish) syntactic structures or they create Nahuat neologisms that are the semantic equivalents of Spanish concepts. Finally, Cuetzalan Nahuat manifests linguistic features that are particular to this language including: (1) alternative applicative forms based on the specificity/lack of specificity of the object, and (2) forms, such as perfectives, that are affected by phonotactic constraints on minimum word forms. All these features are amply documented in recorded natural conversations.

 The social impact of this project has been felt most strongly in the communities studied. Amith's dictionary in electronic form is being used in an alternative Montessori primary school established by the Indigenous collective Tosepan Titataniske with which Amith is collaborating. His field guide has been donated to the same school to promote Indigenous natural history knowledge. During the course of this project Amith has collaborated with four native speakers who have worked full-time on the project. All have become experts in recording, writing, and analyzing their languages and two have developed significant skills in ethnobotanical research. One is now in Mexico City finishing a master's degree in linguistics.
